docs.snippet: Nate Silver, whose FiveThirtyEight blog offers statistical analyses of politics, culture and more, crunches 30 years of Oscar history to help you choose wisely in your Oscar pool....
docs.lead_paragraph: Nate Silver is providing awards-season insight for Carpetbagger leading up to the 83rd Academy Awards on Feb. 27. Mr. Silver is the author of The Times's FiveThirtyEight blog, which is devoted to the analysis of statistics and data in politics and other areas.
docs.abstract: Nate Silver, whose FiveThirtyEight blog offers statistical analyses of politics, culture and more, crunches 30 years of Oscar history to help you choose wisely in your Oscar pool.

headline.main: 4 Rules to Win Your Oscar Pool

docs.snippet: The desire to play outside in your undergarments seems to be a persistent fashion fantasy....
docs.lead_paragraph: Did you suppose that Liz, slipping out of Weston Liggett's Fifth Avenue apartment in a silk slip under a purloined mink, was the first? Or that Bette, when she studiously ignored Eve and Addison at the Cub Room of the Stork Club and claimed she intended to show up for her wedding wearing, "oh, something simple, a fur coat over a nightgown," was an even earlier adopter?
docs.abstract: The desire to play outside in your undergarments seems to be a persistent fashion fantasy.

docs.snippet: The co-chief film critics of The New York Times answer Oscar-related questions about animated film and movies adapted from comic books and novels....
docs.lead_paragraph: Manohla Dargis and A.O. Scott, the co-chief film critics of The New York Times, are answering Oscar-related questions this week, as they kick off what will be a monthly fixture in print and online. For future columns, they would like to hear from you about whatever movie-related subject piques your curiosity: individual films, industry trends, historical trivia. Write to them at askthefilmcritics@nytimes.com.
docs.abstract: The co-chief film critics of The New York Times answer Oscar-related questions about animated film and movies adapted from comic books and novels.

headline.main: The Critics Tackle Some More Oscar Questions

byline.original: By A.O. SCOTT and MANOHLA DARGIS

docs.snippet: "The Gruffalo," up for an Oscar in one of the toughest categories to predict, is one of two nominees based on a celebrated children's book....
docs.lead_paragraph: Fans of Helena Bonham Carter who fear she may not win the Oscar for her supporting role in "The King's Speech" (out-advertised by Melissa Leo or underdogged by Hailee Steinfeld) will be happy to know that Ms. Bonham Carter has a second chance to bring home an Oscar this year, albeit indirectly.
docs.abstract: "The Gruffalo," up for an Oscar in one of the toughest categories to predict, is one of two nominees based on a celebrated children's book.

docs.snippet: Handicapping the competition for the Oscar for best foreign-language film is a bit more complex than for some of the other categories, since there's no telling how many people are going to vote, what motivates those who do, or even who they are....
docs.lead_paragraph: Handicapping the competition for the Oscar for best foreign-language film is a bit more complex than for some of the other categories, since there's no telling how many people are going to vote, what motivates those who do, or even who they are. To qualify to vote, an academy member must see all five nominated films, and many - or most - Oscar voters simply can't be bothered with a category considered so marginal or esoteric. That's not the case with categories like best film or best actor and actress.
docs.abstract: Handicapping the competition for the Oscar for best foreign-language film is a bit more complex than for some of the other categories, since there's no telling how many people are going to vote, what motivates those who do, or even who they are.
